I don't know about the IV stuff, but I do have type 2 diabetes. I test my blood sugar every morning. (Or I'm supposed to, anyway, sometimes I forget). If the results are really high, I test again before dinner, and adjust what I eat. The prednison will raise blood sugar. Did he put you on any medication? If he didn't, checking your blood sugar won't do anything except give you sore fingers, LOL. Ask his nurse, they are usually better relating what you should do than the doctors are. That God for good nurses. They see the reality of patients much more than the lord high almighty doctors do. Good luck, let us know how you are doing........Maggie

Sherma...I am so sorry to hear what you are going through and having to deal with total Moron's for doctor's...have they ever thought of using Google I wonder?  It seems to work well for some of us!When I underwent Steroid treatment with Solumedrol, my Neurologist always insisted that I eat a banana every day that I was getting treatment because the steroid will deplete your level and cause the following problems:Symptoms of Hypokalemia:Hypokalemia ranges from very ornate to severe level. A person suffering from simple/harmless/primary staged hypokalemia may experience no symptoms at all, but general symptoms of hypokalemia are:FatiguePatient may experience problems such as Myalgia and muscular weaknessPatient may experience hyponatremia and also may experience confused i.e. anxiety.Acme problemSkin related problems such as blistering, skin eruptions, dryness of skin etc.Temporary memory loss or problems such as weak memory etc.Patient is prone to heart related problems, such as heart deterioration.Digestive system also may get affected due to potassium deficiency leading to hypertension, improper sleep, nervous system deterioration, depression, constipation etc.In some cases patient may experience ringing/noise in ear.I don't understand why your doc that came to see you wouldn't clue into that and I would mention it to him/her the next time you speak to them.  My neuro said that the amount of potassium contained in a banana would suffice and taking a supplement may be too much which can in turn cause a potassium overdose which apparently is not good either!If you don't like banana's, like me, I can't stand the things, try to eat lot's of potatoes and google other sources of potassium ok?I am pretty sure that if you increase your potassium to a higher lever you will start to feel a whole lot better.Let me know what happens ok?Lots of Hugs,Rena

question: Hi everyone, I hope that you are all feeling OK.  I promised to keep you updated about what went on with my IV.  Well to cut a VERY long story short it has send me into a rebound so now I can't walk or hardly see, and it brought out latent diabetes - great!  I had 500 per day for 5 days and I feel terrible.  I asked the Neuro how long the steroids would stay in my system for and you would not believe what he said "who knows - lets ask the sun and moon and the stars"  - I was speechless.  My normal Doc came around because I can't drive anymore and he said oh you got pre-diabetes here's a kit to test yourself - ciao and off he went.  I have no clue what to do about this but ask my friends on here about the steroids and diabetes.  I been googling around but can't seem to find any answers about how long the drug stays in your system, and how often you test yourself with this silly pin prickler thing.Feeling totally stressed, ectopic heartbeats are back - and this is just after I was starting to feel better after being with my therapist when I THOUGHT I was at my lowest, but it seems yoo can go even lower, but I have positive thooughts in my head and I will not let this get to me I promsise you all that.  I got Wifi so I am typing this from my bed - all I can think of is what the neruo said "sn moom and stars"You are all so good to me,sending loveDebsXXXXXXXXXX
